title: How to Figure Out What Your Parents Got You for Christmas

steps.title: Start with the obvious:
steps.content: Start with the obvious: look in basements, in the trunk of their cars, under beds, on top of shelves. Parents are usually busy and may not have time to hide presents well. If your parents work overtime during the holidays or have a job that is in high demand during the holidays (e.g. department stores or other retail jobs), keep a keen eye out for poorly hidden presents.

steps.title: Examine any suspicious boxes or bags for company or store names as shipped boxes may have a return address.
steps.content: Examine any suspicious boxes or bags for company or store names as shipped boxes may have a return address. If you wanted something from that company, you can get a pretty good idea of what might be inside.

steps.title: Don't look just at the biggest present.
steps.content: Don't look just at the biggest present. They may have bought you tickets to a show you really wanted to go to, or bought you a voucher for a shop you really love. Think about what you want. If you want a car, it will be big, but if you want to go to have your ears pierced, they may just give you a card saying that's what you are going to do. Thinking about the size, shape, and even texture of your present can help you if your parents color-code their gift tags.

steps.title: If you asked for something unusual, consider what they may ask you of this item (where do you get it, what does it do, who else has it...
steps.content: If you asked for something unusual, consider what they may ask you of this item (where do you get it, what does it do, who else has it... ). This means they are at least thinking about buying it.

steps.title: Question siblings.
steps.content: Question siblings. A classic maneuver. Arrange an exchange of information if you must-this is often the case with older siblings. If you are an only child, question cousins or other relatives. For this route, preparing an exchange of information or a bribe will probably be necessary, as they are probably less likely to want to help you snoop.

steps.title: Check bags for store receipts.
steps.content: Check bags for store receipts. They may have information about recent purchases.

steps.title: If still stumped, think about your parents' shopping habits.
steps.content: If still stumped, think about your parents' shopping habits. Did they most likely order your gifts online or did they store-buy? If online, check the order history on their online accounts. Amazon.com keeps lists of all of one's orders-a real jackpot. Most smart parents know what you're trying to do so be VERY sneaky! [1] X Research source

steps.title: If you have a friend owning something you requested (especially something your parents are unfamiliar with), they may call your friend's parents to ask them about it.
steps.content: If you have a friend owning something you requested (especially something your parents are unfamiliar with), they may call your friend's parents to ask them about it. This is a huge clue, but is also easily hidden by parents.

steps.title: Sometimes parents are just last minute shoppers-maybe they haven't gotten you anything yet (there's always Christmas Eve)!
steps.content: Sometimes parents are just last minute shoppers-maybe they haven't gotten you anything yet (there's always Christmas Eve)!

steps.title: The hardest gifts are the ones your parents keep at your neighbor's house.
steps.content: The hardest gifts are the ones your parents keep at your neighbor's house. That includes dogs, bikes, etc. While hard to get clues, try to find where your parents are stashing these gifts, like if your Mom or Dad stops at a neighbor's house after shopping.

steps.title: Parents often leave presents in the car trunk.
steps.content: Parents often leave presents in the car trunk. Usually they keep them there for awhile--for the opportunity to sneak it home or to a neighbor's house. You may be able to sneak a peek at the trunk when you go to the garage for some bogus reason.

steps.title: Though trickier, you can also peek at wrapped gifts.
steps.content: Though trickier, you can also peek at wrapped gifts. This requires some skill and is not for the untrained. If you do unwrap your gift, be sure the return it to its original state.

steps.title: When they are out, check your parents' Internet history to see if they bought or looked at what you asked for.
steps.content: When they are out, check your parents' Internet history to see if they bought or looked at what you asked for. [2] X Research source

steps.title: If you have sheds at your house, or you live on a farm, it is possible that gifts will be hidden there.
steps.content: If you have sheds at your house, or you live on a farm, it is possible that gifts will be hidden there.

steps.title: Take a DVD box and compare to gifts of similar size.
steps.content: Take a DVD box and compare to gifts of similar size. If it rattles, bingo, you've got a disc. It could be a DVD or a video game, especially if that's what you wanted. This is a good, non-invasive method.

steps.title: Feel the boxes of the presents you want, make sure you feel all the soft spots and where exactly they were.
steps.content: Feel the boxes of the presents you want, make sure you feel all the soft spots and where exactly they were. When you get home, feel the boxes wrapped up under the tree, feel the edges and for soft spots, if you know where all the creases of the box, you should know what present it is.

steps.title: If you know how to enter your parent's email/texts do so.
steps.content: If you know how to enter your parent's email/texts do so. Sometimes you could find conformation emails or even have your parents talking about it(ex. Have you bought (your name)'s Xbox yet?)

steps.title: Listen out for subtle slip ups your parents might make that could give away the secret.
steps.content: Listen out for subtle slip ups your parents might make that could give away the secret. For example, if they are thinking about getting you a DVD, they may ask you if your DVD player still works. If they are going to get you a TV, then they may ask you "Can you plug your [DVD player/Chromecast/whatever] into new TVs?". Similar clues are very easy to spot for more technical gifts that your parents don't understand as well as you do (but may be obvious for other gifts also), and while a clue like this is by no means a guarantee of the gift, it's usually a pretty good indicator of it.

steps.title: Make sure to "borrow" all of the supplies that you'll need to open the gift.
steps.content: Make sure to "borrow" all of the supplies that you'll need to open the gift.

steps.title: Make sure you know or have the same wrapping paper as the present, and a lot of it, so you won't have to get caught not being able to wrap it back!
steps.content: Make sure you know or have the same wrapping paper as the present, and a lot of it, so you won't have to get caught not being able to wrap it back!

steps.title: Pad the box with pillows so your parents won't hear the rattling while walking around.
steps.content: Pad the box with pillows so your parents won't hear the rattling while walking around.

steps.title: Put the tape at the bottom.
steps.content: Put the tape at the bottom.

steps.title: Put the scissors next to the tape.
steps.content: Put the scissors next to the tape.

steps.title: Next on top is the wrapping paper.
steps.content: Next on top is the wrapping paper. Then the screwdriver.

steps.title: Also on top place the letter opener, flash light, the paper clips and a blanket.
steps.content: Also on top place the letter opener, flash light, the paper clips and a blanket.

steps.title: Open your gift.
steps.content: Open your gift. Use the scissors to cut the tape.

steps.title: Carefully part the gift wrap, making sure not to tear it.
steps.content: Carefully part the gift wrap, making sure not to tear it.

steps.title: Look at your gift.
steps.content: Look at your gift. Admire your gift. Do not take it to your room or use it.

steps.title: Now, the skilled tape applying:
steps.content: Now, the skilled tape applying: Put strips of tape over cut tape, to hide evidence of cut tape.

steps.title: Put away the gift for now, if you don't like it.
steps.content: Put away the gift for now, if you don't like it. You can replace it. If you didn't replace, keep reading:

steps.title: Once you remember it, like it, and got details, you need to wrap the present all over again.
steps.content: Once you remember it, like it, and got details, you need to wrap the present all over again. Use the same wrapping paper your parents used, and try to wrap the paper the same way as your parents did. Once it is back, put the present back where you found it. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Put all the borrowed supplies back exactly where you found them or your parents will suspect something.
steps.content: Put all the borrowed supplies back exactly where you found them or your parents will suspect something.

steps.title: If you have a bagged present, then this is easy as pie!
steps.content: If you have a bagged present, then this is easy as pie! Just take out the tissue paper carefully and put it back when you're done.

steps.title: You said something like, "I want a new camera someday."
steps.content: You said something like, "I want a new camera someday." Remember stuff you wanted and your parents wanted to get you that for Christmas. Your parents always refresh their minds on Christmas on what to get you.

steps.title: If you gave them a Christmas list, look for it.
steps.content: If you gave them a Christmas list, look for it. They might have crossed out what they already bought.

steps.title: Look in the garage or shed.
steps.content: Look in the garage or shed.
